channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: An undocumented Mexican woman, an undocumented Mexican immigrant, a Lebanese student and an American-born Syrian: They aided investigators after the worst subway attack in decades. Now, they're seeking protection from the nation’s immigration system. https://t.co/iK2yUOpfnj

"You expect us to keep doing this over and over again, forgive and forget," said Garnell Whitfield, a former fire commissioner who lost his mother, Ruth Whitfield, in Saturday's mass shooting in Buffalo. https://t.co/tv6JKjSXuT https://t.co/6Ev0vaUlzq

Australia’s Covid death rate sits at one-tenth of America’s, putting the nation of 25 million people near the top of global rankings in the protection of life. Both countries share similar demographics, but their rates point to different cultures of trust. https://t.co/VQwzMwytVB

Katherine Massey, one of the victims of the mass shooting at a Tops supermarket in Buffalo on Saturday, wrote several commanding letters in local Buffalo publications urging stronger gun control laws. https://t.co/vB6n4JBUEK

At the start of the pandemic, few could imagine that one million people in the U.S. would be lost. It’s a staggering total that struck every corner of the country. But it did not strike evenly. https://t.co/8ht2v7Trxj https://t.co/0BfxVxiPjp

In Opinion
“This Catholic feels an intense disquiet that Catholic doctrine may be shaping (or misshaping) the freedom and the future of millions of women, and men,” Maureen Dowd writes. https://t.co/XY15fgBMsd

Replacement theory, a racist conspiracy espoused by the suspect in the Buffalo massacre, has helped inspire a wave of mass shootings.
Once confined to the fringes, elements of the theory have become a potent force in conservative media and politics. https://t.co/BXVBYe6HbO

Starbucks said it would reimburse travel expenses for employees who need abortions and cannot get them within 100 miles of their homes. In a memo on Monday, the company said it wanted to ensure that its employees had “access to quality health care.” https://t.co/PI1Yg2xKTx

Rep. Liz Cheney, Republican of Wyoming and a former House member of GOP leadership, called out her party’s leaders Monday for enabling the spread of white nationalism after a gunman who believed racist ideology killed 10 people at a Buffalo supermarket. https://t.co/XbZkfndStm https://t.co/kPb9WmFD1U
‘All these innocent lives’: These were the victims in the Buffalo attack. https://t.co/X11cxxg80J https://t.co/zjQ7jBGeZG

Breaking News: President Biden approved a plan to redeploy hundreds of ground forces into Somalia, reviving an open-ended U.S. counterterrorism operation. The move largely reverses Donald Trump's decision to withdraw most troops from the country. https://t.co/uR7uYYK1s1

16 years ago, Dennis DeGray was paralyzed in an accident. Now, implants in his brain allow him to play a video game, manipulate a robotic limb, send texts and emails, purchase products on Amazon and even fly a simulator drone — without lifting a finger. https://t.co/mvNUsHNxWe

Coronavirus cases are spreading at an alarming rate across the U.S., particularly in the Northeast and the Midwest. An average of more than 90,000 new cases are being identified each day, a 60% increase from two weeks ago. https://t.co/5ZbiY6ilO9

Democrats are vowing to push through domestic terrorism legislation to improve intelligence sharing and coordination between law enforcement agencies following the mass shooting in Buffalo — despite growing Republican opposition. https://t.co/StK0HAbMwb
President Vladimir Putin has zealously guarded family from scrutiny. Now sanctions are cracking the wall of secrecy around him. https://t.co/sQS2661u4d

NATO will grant fast-track membership to Sweden and Finland, its secretary general said. The move raises the pressure on President Vladimir Putin, who justified the invasion of Ukraine by what he cast as the need to keep NATO away from Russia’s borders. https://t.co/IrUIXfmefF
Breaking News: McDonald’s is selling its business in Russia after 32 years in the country, where it served as a potent symbol of U.S.-style capitalism. https://t.co/mDJioTe5Al

As the news of the losses at the Donets River crossing in Bilohorivka, Ukraine, started to spread, some Russian bloggers did not appear to hold back in their criticism of what they said was incompetent leadership. https://t.co/8nI7ja4Mgt

Breaking News: The suspect, who authorities said went on to carry out the shooting at a Buffalo grocery store, received a mental health evaluation last year after making threats at a high school, the police said. https://t.co/fsUtplfcuM

Breaking News: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman of Pennsylvania, the front-runner in the state’s Democratic Senate primary, said he was recovering from a stroke. It was unclear when he would return to in-person campaigning before Tuesday's primary. https://t.co/i9t6baBP26

Breaking News: Multiple victims were reported in a shooting at a Southern California church on Sunday. The Orange County Sheriff’s Department said a weapon that might have been involved in the shooting had been recovered and that one person was in custody. https://t.co/aieHucGzR7

Aaron Salter Jr. spent decades with the Buffalo Police Department before retiring and taking a job as a security guard with Tops, the Buffalo grocery store where a gunman killed ten people: "There could have been more victims if not for his actions." https://t.co/1sz5ZCwRBj

Heyward Patterson, who would frequently give people rides to and from the Tops supermarket and help them carry their groceries, was among the 10 people fatally shot in Buffalo, according to his great niece. https://t.co/E0apFHDhwk

Roberta Drury, 32, was killed in the Buffalo shooting, her sister Amanda Drury, 34, said. She was on her way to the Tops supermarket to get groceries to make dinner, she said: "She was very vibrant." https://t.co/dqdkLywJkO

Robert Donald, the owner of a gun store in Endicott, New York, said he sold an assault weapon to the man accused of killing 10 people in Buffalo. Donald said he did a background check on the gunman before he sold him the gun. The report showed nothing. https://t.co/Bh6bhRDleI

The Empire State Trail is a sprawling route that connects Buffalo to Albany and New York City to the Canadian border. It's a showcase of New York State's history and natural beauty. Here's our interactive guide to the highlights. https://t.co/WkSheDoNfr https://t.co/DHL3BIRooB

Celestine Chaney, 65, was killed during the Buffalo shooting, her son, Wayne Jones said. She was visiting her sister and the two of them went to the supermarket because Chaney wanted strawberries to make shortcake. “She loved those,” he said. https://t.co/XfMf4tWuuy

Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York, a day after a mass shooting at a Buffalo supermarket, called on elected officials and business leaders to address the “lethal combination” of hateful ideology online and an overabundance of guns. https://t.co/pxqWiFjsCv https://t.co/BDujcV4GmR

Finland’s government announced on Sunday that it would apply for membership in NATO, a move that would end decades of strategic nonalignment and pave the way for one of the most significant expansions of the Western military alliance in years. https://t.co/IBlgcDEQ6B

The high concentration of Black residents on Buffalo’s East Side, which the suspect in Saturday’s mass shooting said was his reason for targeting the area, is a direct result of decades of segregation and systemic racism, according to decades of research. https://t.co/ylYrIj9SO3

Britney Spears, who was recently released from a conservatorship that had prevented her from becoming pregnant, revealed on Instagram on Saturday that she has had a miscarriage.
https://t.co/FmM0vFF7XE

South Korea remains one of the few countries where tattoo artists are treated as criminals. Tens of thousands of them work in secret under the constant threat of law enforcement — but they say it's time to end the stigma. https://t.co/mUPh8zs9SE

My Chemical Romance announced its breakup in 2013 and released its last new song in 2014. Although the band reunited to tour in 2019, “The Foundations of Decay” is its first new material since then.
Listen to the track and 12 more new songs: https://t.co/ywmWRA7x45

New York University (Taylor's Version)
Taylor Swift will not only be delivering this year's commencement speech, she will also receive an honorary doctorate of fine arts. https://t.co/AZA0Kj7Ajx

Vladimir Putin has viewed the expansion of NATO as an existential threat that would leave Russia hemmed in with Western missiles on its doorstep. Now, his invasion of Ukraine has NATO on the brink of its largest potential expansion in nearly two decades. https://t.co/ZNko8WWRAS

An 18-year-old white male who traveled from outside Buffalo was in custody after an attack at a Tops grocery store that officials said was racially motivated. Eleven of the 13 people who were shot were Black. https://t.co/ZpsgpZrPZ6
No, the Biden administration is not sending baby formula to undocumented immigrants at the expense of American families amid a national shortage. https://t.co/YefeU7whSN

The Ukrainian rap and folk band Kalush Orchestra won the Eurovision Song Contest on Saturday, as European viewers and juries delivered a symbolic, pop culture endorsement of solidarity behind Ukraine in its defense against Russia’s invasion.
https://t.co/BLrjbrszJ5 https://t.co/l2NkatfXmw
The front page of The New York Times for Sunday, May 15, 2022. https://t.co/NouHgbxIAL

Thousands of marchers converged in the nation’s capital and across the country on Saturday to show their support for abortion rights nearly two weeks after the leak of a Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade. https://t.co/Tw2yGnVEY1 https://t.co/73qT7T4cwd

Ernie Barnes’s most famous painting, “Sugar Shack,” an exultant dancing scene featured on the cover of Marvin Gaye’s album “I Want You” and during the closing credits of TV’s “Good Times,” sold for $15.3 million at Christie’s. https://t.co/mkiL5hkyXN

Senator Mitch McConnell and three other Republican senators visited Ukraine on Saturday to meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky. The trip highlights the widespread bipartisan support for Ukraine in Washington. https://t.co/kvIL1QwWho https://t.co/yCGkyN0MQD

Nearly one million people have died of Covid in the U.S. since the pandemic began. The deaths came in wave after wave and left no corner of the country untouched. https://t.co/GEgsY0db1K https://t.co/GlCgTKZIH2

Justice Clarence Thomas said on Friday night the leak of a draft opinion has done irreparable damage to the Supreme Court and that it had destroyed trust among the members. He also decried the protests at justices’ homes. https://t.co/sKgi6XKul0
Many adults under 35 have stopped playing it safe. Instead of saving, they’re spending more and pursuing passion projects or risky careers. https://t.co/i8QgTst4y6 https://t.co/J7g4WTcuSq
President Vladimir Putin has zealously guarded family from scrutiny. Now sanctions are cracking the wall of secrecy around him. https://t.co/jTxlTq2K7t https://t.co/W9LdQS6PaI

Palestinians gathered on Thursday to honor Shireen Abu Akleh, the Al Jazeera journalist who was fatally shot on Wednesday. The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, described her as a “martyr for truth and for the free word.” https://t.co/A5AUj1uJwY

In the Republican primary for Pennsylvania's open Senate seat, Kathy Barnette, a Black mother of two who has never held office and whose life story has moved many white anti-abortion conservatives, poses a late threat to the two presumptive favorites. https://t.co/FxNMWs7xk9

Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky on Thursday single-handedly delayed a bipartisan effort to quickly send $40 billion in aid to Ukraine, which Congress had tried to fast-track amid the escalating brutality of Russia’s war. https://t.co/7QAk4xGZIY

Former employees said the Las Vegas Raiders organization is in disarray, citing executive departures, poor financial management, unpaid electric bills and a raft of firings, payouts and NDAs. https://t.co/ZMNuoAJrUp
